document_title: Draft Genome Sequences of Several Fungal Strains Selected for Exposure to Microgravity at the International Space Station
summary_full: This paper presents the draft whole-genome sequences of eight fungal strains chosen for exposure to microgravity on the International Space Station (ISS). These strains were isolated from environments associated with the Chernobyl nuclear power plant or soil and are known for producing valuable natural products, possessing secondary metabolism pathways, or exhibiting radiotropism. The selected fungi include Aspergillus niger, Aspergillus terreus, Aureobasidium pullulans, Beauveria bassiana, Cladosporium cladosporioides, Cladosporium sphaerospermum, Fusarium solani, and Trichoderma virens. Their genomes were sequenced using the Illumina HiSeq2500 platform and assembled using the MaSuRCA genome assembler. These baseline genomic sequences are intended to facilitate future research into the production of novel bioactive compounds by these fungi under microgravity conditions.
key_findings: Draft whole-genome sequences for eight fungal strains selected for ISS microgravity experiments have been generated.
The selected fungal strains originate from diverse environments, including the Chernobyl nuclear power plant.
These strains are known for their potential to produce valuable natural products and possess relevant metabolic pathways.
Genomic sequencing was performed using Illumina HiSeq2500, and assembly was done with MaSuRCA.
The generated genome data will serve as a baseline for understanding microgravity's effects on fungal bioactive compound production.
future_research_fields: Investigating the production of novel bioactive compounds by these fungi under microgravity.
Analyzing the genetic basis for radiation tolerance and radiotropism in these fungal strains.
Exploring the biotechnological potential of these fungi for industrial applications.
Understanding the role of secondary metabolism pathways in fungal adaptation to space environments.

conclusions: The generation of draft genome sequences for these eight fungal strains provides a foundational resource for future studies, particularly those investigating the impact of microgravity on their biological activities and the production of novel bioactive compounds.
impact_statement: This work provides essential genomic data for fungi selected for spaceflight experiments, enabling future discoveries in astrobiology and the development of novel biotechnological applications.
